sn22.81:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn22.81:1.2: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.
sn22.81:1.3: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order himself. Taking his bowl and robe, without informing his attendants or taking leave of the bhikkhu Saṅgha, he set out to go wandering alone, with no companion.
sn22.81:2.1: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, one of the bhikkhus went to Venerable Ānanda and told him what had happened.
sn22.81:2.3: Venerable Ānanda said, “Friend, when the Buddha leaves like this it means he wants to stay alone.
sn22.81:2.4: At this time no-one should follow him.”
sn22.81:3.1: Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage, arrived at Pārileyya,
sn22.81:3.2: where he stayed at the root of a sacred sal tree.
sn22.81:3.3: Then several bhikkhus went up to Venerable Ānanda and exchanged pleasantries with him.
sn22.81:3.4: When the amicable and cordial talk was over, they sat down to one side and said to him,
sn22.81:3.5: “Friend, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
sn22.81:3.6: We wish to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
sn22.81:4.1: Then Venerable Ānanda together with those bhikkhus went to Pārileyya to see the Buddha. They bowed and sat down to one side,
sn22.81:4.2: and the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
sn22.81:4.3: Now at that time one of the bhikkhus had the thought,
sn22.81:4.4: “For one who knows and sees in which way is there immediately the exhaustion of the influxes?”
sn22.81:4.5: Then the Buddha, knowing what that bhikkhu was thinking, addressed the bhikkhus:
sn22.81:4.7: I’ve thoroughly explained the four establishments of recollection,
sn22.81:4.9: the four bases of spiritual ability,
sn22.81:4.14: That’s how I’ve explained the Dhamma thoroughly.
sn22.81:4.15: Though I’ve explained the Dhamma thoroughly like this, still a certain bhikkhu present here has this thought:
sn22.81:4.16: “For one who knows and sees in which way is there immediately the exhaustion of the influxes?”
sn22.81:5.1: And for one who knows and sees in which way, bhikkhus, is there the exhaustion of the influxes?
sn22.81:5.2: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
sn22.81:5.4: But that regarding is an activity.
sn22.81:5.5: And what’s the foundation, origin, birthplace, and source of that activity?
sn22.81:5.6: For an unlearned ordinary person, struck by feelings born of ignorance-contact, craving is there.
sn22.81:5.7: That activity is born from that.
sn22.81:5.8: So that activity is impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:5.11: and that ignorance are also impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:5.12: For one who knows and sees in this way, bhikkhus, there is immediate exhaustion of the influxes.
sn22.81:6.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form as self,
sn22.81:6.2: but they still regard self as possessing form.
sn22.81:6.3: But that regarding is an activity. …
sn22.81:7.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form,
sn22.81:7.2: but they still regard form in self.
sn22.81:7.3: But that regarding is an activity. …
sn22.81:8.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form, or form in self,
sn22.81:8.2: but they still regard self in form.
sn22.81:8.3: But that regarding is an activity. …
sn22.81:9.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form, or form in self, or self in form.
sn22.81:9.2: But they regard feeling as self …
sn22.81:9.6: But that regarding is an activity.
sn22.81:9.7: And what’s the foundation, origin, birthplace, and source of that activity?
sn22.81:9.8: For an unlearned ordinary person, struck by feelings born of ignorance-contact, craving is there.
sn22.81:9.9: That activity is born from that.
sn22.81:9.10: So that activity is impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:9.14: and that ignorance are also impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:9.15: For one who knows and sees in this way, bhikkhus, there is immediate exhaustion of the influxes.
sn22.81:10.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form
sn22.81:10.6: Still, they have such a view:
sn22.81:10.7: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:10.8: But that eternalist view is an activity.
sn22.81:10.9: And what’s the foundation of that activity? …
sn22.81:10.10: For one who knows and sees in this way, bhikkhus, there is immediate exhaustion of the influxes.
sn22.81:11.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form
sn22.81:11.6: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:11.7: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:11.8: Still, they have such a view:
sn22.81:11.9: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.81:11.10: But that annihilationist view is an activity.
sn22.81:11.11: And what’s the foundation of that activity? …
sn22.81:11.15: For one who knows and sees in this way, bhikkhus, there is immediate exhaustion of the influxes.
sn22.81:12.1: Or perhaps they don’t regard form or feeling
sn22.81:12.5: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:12.6: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After passing away I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:12.7: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:12.8: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.81:12.9: Still, they have doubts and uncertainties. They’re undecided about the true teaching.
sn22.81:12.10: That doubt and uncertainty, the indecision about the true teaching, is an activity.
sn22.81:12.11: And what’s the foundation of that activity?
sn22.81:12.12: For an unlearned ordinary person, struck by feelings born of ignorance-contact, craving is there.
sn22.81:12.13: That activity is born from that.
sn22.81:12.14: So that activity is impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:12.18: and that ignorance are also impermanent, determined, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:12.19: For one who knows and sees in this way, bhikkhus, there is immediate exhaustion of the influxes.”
